active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the strengths and limitations of DREAD compared to other models like CVSS or STRIDE. Provide examples from real-world breaches (e.g., Equifax SQL injection) where DREAD scoring could have prioritized remediation effectively. What thresholds (e.g., 0-20 Low) would you adjust for your organization's context?
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Threat Modeling (DREAD Score Calculation). Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Threat Modeling > Threat Modeling Methodologies and Frameworks > DREAD Risk Assessment > DREAD Score Calculation. Core Content: DREAD (Damage Potential, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected Users, Discoverability) - score each 0-10, sum for 0-50 total. Risk levels: 0-20 Low, 21-35 Medium, 36-50 High. Example: SQL Injection (Damage=9, Reproducibility=10, Exploitability=8, Affected Users=7, Discoverability=9; Total=43, High). Prior knowledge: STRIDE threats. Big picture: Prioritize in SDLC lifecycle. Learning Objectives: [INSERT FULL LIST FROM ABOVE]. Scaffolding Layers: [INSERT FULL LAYERS FROM ABOVE]. Active Learning: Use for inspiration in explanations. Generate 40 high-quality flashcards following this EXACT schema: {{flashcard_schema_structure_here}} - Cover all layers progressively (scaffolding). - Span Bloom's levels per objectives. - 70% MCQ with 3 distractors (protocol: misconceptions, swaps, partial calcs). - 20% cloze/basic for recall. - 10% scenario/create for higher levels. - Ensure active recall: questions test application/analysis. - Explanations: pedagogical, reference objectives/layers, link to real-world (e.g., SQL inj), voter-completed prioritization. Output as JSON array: [{'front': '...', 'back': {'correct_answer': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'hints': [...], 'source_layer': 'Layer X', 'bloom_level': 'APPLY'}, 'distractors': ['A', 'B', 'C']}, ...]. No extra text.
